title.narrative: TAF - TA Implementation - Cooperative - CABF - Ivory Coast

description.narrative:
CABF is a cocoa cooperative that started in 2004 with 127 cocoa members. It currently has 2 868 farmers of which 63 are women (2%) and 430 are young (15%). It is located in Zégban in the Southern Region of Côte d’Ivoire. The cooperative has gone through a diversification process going beyond the trading of cocoa and expanding to raw cashew nut and rubber processed cup film.

With a total membership strength of 2 868 1 775 (62%) are cocoa and rubber producers and 1 093 (38%) are cashew nut producers. In 2018 cocoa contributed 95.75% to total revenues and rubber contributed the rest (4.25%). No revenues were made from cashew nut. CABF’s primary activity was the trade of cocoa beans and cashew nuts. In addition to growing cocoa and cashew nuts several members of the cooperative also produce rubber and palm oil. In June 2018 the Board of Directors decided to add these two crops to the cooperative's activity.

This project is created as result of the implementation of the proposed Technical Assistance following the Due Diligence carried out in September 2019.

The TAF was created by IFAD as a separate mechanism linked to the ABC Fund which provides advisory services to agricultural organizations and SMEs allowing them to access new partnership and business development opportunities.

• Strategic plan: Strategic business planning workshop with lead members and follow-up coaching trajectory
  • Child labour: exchange mission giving advice on the implementation of a child labour prevention system within the cooperative
  • Monitoring Operations: advice mission on guidance and monitoring of financing portfolios and sales contracts especially with the diversification underway in the cooperative
